title: Cyclistic Customer Analysis
text:
Analysis


Code
basic <- bike_rides %>%
  group_by(
    user_bike,
    month
  ) %>%
  summarise(
    rides = n(),
    duration = median(as.numeric(ride_time, units = "minutes"))
  )




Code
basic %>%
  ggplot(
    aes(
      month, duration,
      group = user_bike,
      colour = user_bike
    )
  ) +
  geom_line() +
  scale_x_date(
    breaks = scales::breaks_width("2 months"),
    labels = scales::label_date("%b %Y", tz = "America/Chicago")
  ) +
  ylim(0, 30.5) +
  labs(
    x = NULL,
    y = "Median ride duration in minutes",
    colour = "Segment"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()





Figure 4: Median ride duration by market segment




Figure 4 shows the median ride time for each month for the five combinations of bicycle and user type. Member rides are consistently shorter than casual rides.
Casual-Docked consistently has the longest median ride duration and appears to capture rides taken on a day pass. For this analysis I have assumed that Casual-Docked rides are primarily visitor traffic. As visitors are unlikely to take up membership, they can be dropped from the analysis.
Both member and casual groups electric bikes have a shorter ride duration than classic bikes.
Cyclistic pricing changed on 10 May 2022. The changes reduced the casual unlock fee from $3.30 to $1.00 and removed 30 minutes included time for classic bikes and e-bike trips. There is an indication that the median duration for Casual-Classic and Casual-Electric trips has declined from May 2022 onwards.


Code
day_rides <- bike_rides %>%
  filter(bike_type != "Docked") %>%
  mutate(weekend = if_else(
    dayw %in% c("Sat", "Sun"),
    "Weekend",
    "Weekday"
  )) %>%
  group_by(
    user_bike,
    yday = floor_date(started_at, "day")
  ) %>%
  summarise(
    weekend,
    duration_mins = as.numeric(median(ride_time)) / 60
  )




Code
basic %>%
  ggplot(aes(
    month, rides,
    group = user_bike,
    colour = user_bike
  )) +
  geom_line() +
  scale_y_continuous(
    breaks = scales::breaks_width(50000),
    labels = scales::label_comma()
  ) +
  scale_x_date(
    breaks = scales::breaks_width("2 months"),
    labels = scales::label_date("%b %Y", tz = "America/Chicago")
  ) +
  labs(
    x = NULL,
    y = "Rides per month",
    colour = "Segment"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()





Figure 5: Rides per month by market segment






Code
m <- day_rides %>%
  group_by(
    user_bike,
    weekend
  ) %>%
  summarise(
    mean_duration = mean(duration_mins)
  )

day_rides %>%
  ggplot(
    aes(
      duration_mins,
      colour = weekend,
      group = weekend,
      alpha = 0.7
    )
  ) +
  geom_density(adjust = 3) +
  geom_vline(
    data = m,
    aes(
      xintercept = mean_duration,
      colour = weekend,
      alpha = 0.8
    )
  ) +
  facet_grid(
    rows = vars(user_bike)
  ) +
  guides(
    alpha = "none"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  xlim(0, 25) +
  labs(
    x = "Median daily ride duration",
    colour = "Day Type"
  )
